Introduction to zipcodeR

Gavin Rozzi

Source: vignettes/zipcodeR.Rmd
zipcodeR.Rmd

zipcodeR is an all-in-one toolkit for working with ZIP codes in R.

This document will introduce the tools provided by zipcodeR for improving your workflow when working with ZIP code-level data. The goal of these examples is to help you quickly get up and running with zipcodeR.

Data: U.S. Real Estate Market

To explore how zipcodeR can enhance your data & workflow, we will use a public dataset from the National Association of Realtors containing data about housing price trends in the United States.

This dataset contains 12291 observations with current housing market data from the National Association of Realtors hosted on Amazon S3

This is what the data we will be working with looks like:

head(real_estate_data)

Searching for ZIP codes by state

Letâ€™s begin by using zipcodeR to find all ZIP codes within a given state.

Searching by county

It is also possible to search for ZIP codes given the county name

Approximate matching

Getting extra data for a ZIP code

Finding Census tracts in ZIP codes

You may need to allocate data at the ZIP code level to Census tracts. This is easy using the get_tracts() function.

Letâ€™s find out how many Census tracts are in the ZIP code

get_tracts("10001")
## 11 Census tracts found for ZIP code 10001
## # A tibble: 11 x 3
##    ZCTA5 TRACT        GEOID
##    <chr> <chr>        <dbl>
##  1 10001 005800 36061005800
##  2 10001 007600 36061007600
##  3 10001 009100 36061009100
##  4 10001 009300 36061009300
##  5 10001 009500 36061009500
##  6 10001 009700 36061009700
##  7 10001 009900 36061009900
##  8 10001 010100 36061010100
##  9 10001 010300 36061010300
## 10 10001 010900 36061010900
## 11 10001 011100 36061011100

Now that you have all of the tracts for this ZIP code, it would be trivial to join this with other Census data, such as that which is available from the tidycensus package.
